--------------------

>--- J. B. Rainsbergerwrote:
>> Do I understand correctly?
>
>Not completely, but that is just because you have to deal with the 
>information I give to you :-). I think that your questions are 
>justified given the available info. 
<snip />

From what I read, you are trying to do something that JUnit does not
do, so your only choices are to change what you do or change JUnit.
Either write your test so that setUp cannot throw an exception or
change the test runner to recover from the situation where setUp throws
an exception -- the recovery involves writing out the </test> tag.

If you want to use JUnit as is, though, setUp can't throw an exception.
It shouldn't, anyway. That usually means that the test or the
environment is messed up, and usually has nothing to do with your
production code.

Good luck.


J. B. Rainsberger,
